case_vignette: A 12-YEAR-OLD BOY PRESENTS TO THE DERMATOLOGY CLINIC WITH A 2-YEAR HISTORY OF A BROWN PATCH ON HIS CHEST. THE 8-CM PATCH HAD BEEN ASYMPTOMATIC, BUT OVER THE PAST 6 MONTHS, IT HAS BECOME DARKER, WITH HAIR AND ACNE VULGARIS DEVELOPING WITHIN THE LESION. THE PATIENT IS SELF-CONSCIOUS ABOUT THE LESION’S APPEARANCE AND WISHES TO LEARN IF IT CAN BE TREATED TO LESSEN THE HYPERPIGMENTATION.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a brown patch on my chest that has become darker, developed hair and acne over the past six months.
How old are you and what is your gender?
I am a 12-year-old boy.
Has the size of the patch changed since you first noticed it?
No, the size of the patch has not changed.
Do you have any similar patches elsewhere on your body?
No, I have no similar patches elsewhere on my body.
Is there any history of similar skin problems in your family?
I'm not sure about any similar skin problems in my family.
Have you experienced any changes in sensation, such as itching or pain, in the affected area?
No, the patch has been asymptomatic; I haven’t experienced any itching or pain.
Final Diagnosis: Becker's Nevus

The size of the patch remains unchanged, and there are no similar patches elsewhere on the patient's body. Furthermore, the patient is unsure about any familial history of similar skin issues. The patch has been asymptomatic, exhibiting no itching or pain.
